Core Course: Privatization and Regulation of Transport Services
Ray C. Rist WBI Evaluation Unit World Bank Natalie Deveaux Advisor Evaluation Analyst (202) 458-5625 (202) 473-1399
Number 15 September 1998
Estache, Antonio (Notation: The World Bank Institute was formerly called the Economic Development Institute (EDI), as reflected in some text)
The Regulatory Reform and Private Enterprise Division of The Economic Development Institute (EDIRP) conducted a core course on Privatization and Regulation of Transport Services in Washington, DC from January 5-13, 1998. The course objective was to provide transport regulators and policy makers with the necessary tools to address the main issues that typically arise after privatization. It aimed at enhancing their economic, technical, and policy making skills, enabling them to contribute to significant improvements in the implementation of day to day regulatory responsibilities and transport policies.
Forty-five participants attended the seminar, which was evaluated by the EDI Evaluation Unit (EDIES). A questionnaire was used to evaluate the first week of the course on aspects of course relevance and effectiveness of resource persons, and also to compare knowledge of the participants before and after the course. The questionnaire used a six point scale ranging from 1=minimum to 6=maximum. Of the 45 participants, 39 (87%) completed questionnaires. The major evaluation findings are summarized below.
· Overall response on the course performance was positive. The mean for all responses was greater than 4.00. This suggests that respondents perceived that the course helped them to improve their knowledge and abilities in the area of privatization and regulation of transport services.
· The course was considered highly relevant to the respondents' needs. Almost 85 percent of participant respondents fell into the 5-6 range on this question. Moreover, this item received the highest mean score (5.05) on this section of the evaluation.
· A second item that received high mean scores asked whether the course was a worthwhile use of participants' time. The average mean score of this question was 5.03.
· The evaluation shows that one area requiring attention may be "clarifying the next steps for participants to take regarding privatization and regulation of transport services". This item received the lowest mean score (4.69). Course designers may need to put more emphasis on this item.
· There was positive feedback on resource persons' knowledge of the issues. The range of mean scores for this category was 4.94 to 5.49. Favorable responses were also given for their communication skills. The range of mean scores for this was 4.11 to 5.49. One of the key presenters, Mr. Gomez-Ibanez, was distinguished with top mean scores in both knowledge (mean=5.49) and communication skills (mean=5.54).
· For 5 of the 6 items addressing the content of the first week of the course, the lowest score received was a 3.0 out of 6. A sixth item, asking to what extent the first week of the course was a worthwhile use of time, received no scores lower than 4 out of 6. A score of 6 was given at least once for all items in that section of the evaluation. The section that focused on resource persons'  knowledge and communication skills showed more variability. 'Minimum' scores ranged from 1 to 4 while 'maximum' scores were consistent at the 6 level.
· Comparison of the ratings at the beginning and at the end of the first week shows that participants' perceived knowledge improved. Mean scores before the start of the course ranged from 3.00 to 3.85. After the first week, scores improved to a range of 4.33 to 4.85.
· Maximum perceived gain in knowledge was on the topic addressing the "importance of the difference between role of return and price cap regulation". The pre/post change for this item was 1.38.
· The smallest gain achieved was for the topic covering the "problems governments face in regulating private sector transport provisions. The change noted for this was 0.95.
· There were some limitations to this evaluation. First, only 7 days of the 9 day course were evaluated. In addition, the evaluation judged only perceived knowledge gain as opposed to actual knowledge gain. Finally, there is no mid-point on the six point Likert type scale used, which may be problematic for respondents, as it provides no true mid-point measure. These limitations should be considered when planning evaluations of future courses.
